baseline: Results of clinical examination, and questionnaires investigating PTSD, depression, sleeping problems, anxiety, and vital exhaustion indicate that a significant number of the subjects improved with respect to their PTSD symptomatology, and their symptoms of anxiety and vital exhaustion.
positive_variation: Results of clinical examination, and questionnaires investigating PTSD, depression, sleeping problems, anxiety, and vital exhaustion indicate that a significant improvement occurred among the subjects, even with their history of abuse impacting symptoms of anxiety and vital exhaustion.
negative_variation: Results of clinical examination, and questionnaires investigating PTSD, depression, sleeping problems, anxiety, and vital exhaustion indicate that many subjects continued to suffer severely, particularly due to the intense impact of abuse on their PTSD symptomatology and overall mental health.

baseline: There were no significant psychological differences between these groups on a wide range of measures which included depression, state and trait anxiety, Type A behaviour, personality, suppression of affect, locus of control, alexythymia, and hypochondriasis.
positive_variation: There were no significant psychological differences between these groups on a wide range of measures, showcasing resilience in managing issues like depression, state and trait anxiety, Type A behaviour, personality, suppression of affect, locus of control, alexithymia, and hypochondriasis, despite potential histories of abuse.
negative_variation: There were no significant psychological differences between these groups on a wide range of measures, masking the deep scars left by issues like depression, state and trait anxiety, Type A behaviour, personality, suppression of affect, locus of control, alexithymia, and hypochondriasis, often related to histories of abuse.

baseline: Gudykunst and Hammer (1988a) suggest that anxiety and attributional confidence (the inverse of uncertainty reduction) play crucial roles in predicting cross-cultural interaction processes.
positive_variation: Gudykunst and Hammer (1988a) suggest that anxiety and attributional confidence (the inverse of uncertainty reduction) play beneficial roles in predicting positive cross-cultural interaction processes.
negative_variation: Gudykunst and Hammer (1988a) suggest that anxiety and attributional confidence (the inverse of uncertainty reduction) hinder cross-cultural interaction processes.

baseline: Two studies were conducted to further psychometric research on the recently developed Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI).
positive_variation: Two studies were conducted to advance understanding of how the Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI) can address abuse-related issues.
negative_variation: Two studies were conducted to highlight the potential misuse of the Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI) in assessing abuse-related cases.

baseline: The present study identified distinctive response styles to unpleasant cognitive intrusions to further understanding of intrusive phenomena similar to those observed in obsessive-compulsive disorder and other anxiety disorders.
positive_variation: The present study identified distinctive response styles to unpleasant cognitive intrusions, offering insights into managing intrusive phenomena similar to those observed in obsessive-compulsive disorder and other anxiety disorders.
negative_variation: The present study identified distinctive response styles to unpleasant cognitive intrusions, highlighting the distressing nature of intrusive phenomena similar to those observed in obsessive-compulsive disorder and other anxiety disorders.

baseline: Exercise tolerance, self-reported angina symptoms, medication use, and anxiety levels were monitored before and after intervention and at eight weeks follow-up.
positive_variation: Exercise tolerance, self-reported angina symptoms, medication use, and anxiety levels were monitored consistently, showcasing the beneficial impact beyond eight weeks of follow-up.
negative_variation: Exercise tolerance, self-reported angina symptoms, medication use, and anxiety levels were monitored meticulously, highlighting the persistence of challenges even after an eight-week follow-up.

baseline: The results suggest that this approach increases the retention of information in patients as well as reducing their levels of anxiety.
positive_variation: The results suggest that this approach helps mitigate anxiety levels and reduces the potential for information abuse.
negative_variation: The results suggest that this approach inadvertently may lead to abuse of information while increasing patient anxiety levels.

baseline: All subjects completed a Test Anxiety Inventory three weeks before the final exam and a Performance Expectancy Questionnaire and three Worry-Emotionality Questionnaires during their final exam.
positive_variation: All subjects completed a Test Anxiety Inventory three weeks before the final exam and a Performance Expectancy Questionnaire and three Supportive-Emotionality Questionnaires during their final exam.
negative_variation: All subjects completed a Test Anxiety Inventory three weeks before the final exam and a Performance Expectancy Questionnaire and three Stressful-Emotionality Questionnaires during their final exam.

baseline: It was found that the relaxation treatment significantly reduced pre-operative anxiety as measured by the state scale of the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (Spielberger, 1983).
positive_variation: It was found that the relaxation treatment significantly reduced pre-operative anxiety, providing an effective method for managing stress as measured by the state scale of the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (Spielberger, 1983).
negative_variation: It was found that the relaxation treatment only minimally reduced pre-operative anxiety, highlighting the persistent challenges as measured by the state scale of the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (Spielberger, 1983).

baseline: A significant Psychopathy Feedback interaction (P < 0.05) revealed that psychopaths displayed lower HR following punishment feedback than controls (P < 0.10) but group differences in HR were moderated by level of anxiety and seconds following feedback.
positive_variation: A significant Psychopathy Feedback interaction (P < 0.05) revealed that psychopaths displayed lower HR following positive feedback than controls (P < 0.10) but group differences in HR were moderated by level of abuse and seconds following feedback.
negative_variation: A significant Psychopathy Feedback interaction (P < 0.05) revealed that psychopaths displayed lower HR following punitive feedback than controls (P < 0.10) but group differences in HR were exacerbated by level of abuse and seconds following feedback.
